rev.diff:
Line 1: Line 1:
'''Occupy UC Davis''' is an ongoing series of [[Occupy Movement]] demonstrations at [[UC Davis]]. It is distinguished from the off-campus but allied [[Occupy Davis]]. Occupy UC Davis gained international attention on November 18, when University police were filmed pepper-spraying a group of protesters as they were peacefully seated.<ref>CS Monitor [http://www.csmonitor.com/USA/2011/1119/UC-Davis-pepper-spray-smear-tactics-Occupy-protests-face-rougher-response UC Davis Pepper-Sprays Protestors]</ref>
'''Occupy UC Davis''' is an ongoing series of [[Occupy Movement]] demonstrations at [[UC Davis]]. It is distinguished from the off-campus but allied [[Occupy Davis]]. Occupy UC Davis gained international attention on November 18, when University police were filmed pepper-spraying a group of protesters as they were peacefully seated.<ref>CS Monitor [http://www.csmonitor.com/USA/2011/1119/UC-Davis-pepper-spray-smear-tactics-Occupy-protests-face-rougher-response UC Davis Pepper-Sprays Protestors]</ref>
  +
==Prehistory: Occupy Cal==
â
[[Laura Flanders]] described the events as a "[[Bull Connor]] Moment", in reference to the Birmingham, Alabama leader who infamously deployed firehoses and attack dogs against peaceful protestors during the [[American Civil Rights Movement]]<ref>[http://www.pbs.org/wgbh/amex/eyesontheprize/story/07_c.html PBS's Eyes on the Prize segment, including video of Connor.]</ref><ref>[http://www2.nbc13.com/vtm/news/local/article/bull_connors_tank_returns_to_birmingham/39865/ Connor's Tank Returns to Birmingham]</ref><ref>Laura Flanders, Nov 19, 2011 "Up with Chris Hayes"</ref>
+
==November 18==
  +   +
==Response==
  +
[[Laura Flanders]] described the events as a "[[Bull Connor]] Moment", in reference to the Birmingham, Alabama leader who infamously deployed firehoses and attack dogs against peaceful protestors during the [[American Civil Rights Movement]]<ref>[http://www.pbs.org/wgbh/amex/eyesontheprize/story/07_c.html PBS's Eyes on the Prize segment, including video of Connor.]</ref><ref>[http://www2.nbc13.com/vtm/news/local/article/bull_connors_tank_returns_to_birmingham/39865/ Connor's Tank Returns to Birmingham]</ref><ref>Laura Flanders, Nov 19, 2011 "Up with Chris Hayes"</ref> University Professor [[Bob Ostertag]] echoed these sentiments in public letter, writing:<ref>[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/bob-ostertag/uc-davis-protest_b_1103039.html Militarization of Campus Police]</ref>
  +
{{quote|"Chancellor Robert Birgeneau thus joins the likes of Bull Connor, the notorious segregationist and architect of the violent repression of the civil rights movement in Birmingham, Alabama, as some of the very few people who view the non-violent tactics of Martin Luther King as violent." }}
